Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 07:53PM linnyhopp wrote: Stacey...I experienced the same side effect.  Grossed my husband out!   With all the other stuff going on through chemo, I was glad to find out it was a "normal" side effect.  Yes, my expectations dropped quite a bit during that time, but once you are through with treatment, you will be amazed at how strong you really are!
Posts.Title: bloody nose? stacey5971 stacey5971

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 12:22AM linnyhopp wrote: Chicken...can't stand the sight of it raw and can only eat it now if I don't cook it! Mashed potatoes and mac n cheese run a close second.  Eeuuww!
Posts.Title: What did you eat during Chemo that you cannot stand after Chemo? Denise-G Cottontail

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2012 08:31PM linnyhopp wrote: Just wanted to add that I am an office manager in an elementary school and my onc was not really too happy that I wanted to work due to all the illnesses kids seem to share with the adults.  I had to convince him that being in my own office allowed me to stay away from most of the germs.  I did work when I felt well enough.  However, one of my teacher friends was diagnosed several months after me and her onc stronly advised she not work (and she didn't) during chemo for the same reason.  However, I know there are several teachers who have posted that they continued working so it must be a possibility even when working directly with students.  And, yes, I do think working when you can does wonders to make you feel some normalcy during treatment.  Linda
Posts.Title: Relocation for treatment??? Krissy5 wenweb

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2013 12:49AM linnyhopp wrote: Hi Everyone...I am sure there must be a post here somewhere, but I am admitting that I am too lazy to go back and read posts from "way back when."  I finished Herceptin last November and that is when my hair started growing more quickly.  I have finally had to ditch my wig because I couldn't stuff all of the hair in the back into the wig.  The reason I kept wearing it so long (and am tempted to put it back on) is because the front of my head has hair that looks like it has been fried and is very thing.  The bang and areas of the side are very hard to manage and the top of my hair is very thin.  I am wondering if anyone has had issues with certain areas that are in much worse shape than others?  I am so hoping that it will grow out with the dry and frizzy look and feel gone.  I went to Ulta today and checked out the Nioxin, but don't know if that would even help.  I would so appreciate any input from those who have had similar hair issues.  Thanks in advance for any help you can give me.   Linda
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 02:46PM linnyhopp wrote: Hi to everyone...I know that if I read all of the postings, I could probably find the answer to my question.  Since I don't have the time or the energy, I am going to ask my question and hope someone will have pity on me and reply.  I have been finished with chemo and Herceptin for over a year and my hair has grown in and for that I am grateful.  However, my hair looks dry and frizzy no matter what I use on it.  My stylist doesn't seem to have any more suggestions for me.  I do use the argon (sp) oil she receommended, but it still has that "frayed" look to it.  Has anyone else experienced this and if so, is there a remedy you can share?  Thanks for any help or suggestions you might share.  Linda
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 08:03PM linnyhopp wrote: Hi to All!  This is my first post on this board.  I am 7 weeks past chemo (TCH) as of today and my hair is not growing.  There is a bit of fuzz in the back like a 5 o'clock shadow, but the front is just about the same as it was during chemo.  I am doing Herceptin and radiation so I guess that could slow things down.  I am getting nervous and very impatient!  You probably all know that I am thinking I am one of those rare people who won't get my hair back.  Do you think that since there is some growth in back I will eventually look like me again someday?  Linda
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 01:21AM linnyhopp wrote: Thanks, Racy...so wonderful of you to wish me well.  Here's hoping all going through this have an easy time of it.  I love the saying I found on here (at least I think it was here), "You don't have to be brave, you just have to show up!"  Got a copy of it in my kitchen and even my husband uses it to make me believe I can do it!

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 01:25AM linnyhopp wrote: Survivor11: Trying to keep the faith on this whole thing.  First chemo is less than 12 hours away now...yikes...have been drinking water like a sponge and the night ahead should be interesting between all the steroids and the potty trips.  Hope I will be able to stay positive when the hair goes. Can't seem to get past that, but it seems like most say once it's gone, you just move on.  Hope that's true for me.  A Very Good Night to all and will post later.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 03:51PM - edited Sep 28, 2012 12:46AM by linnyhopp I made an appointment with my wonderful wig stylist (who is a 10 year colon cancer survivor) about 2 1/2 weeks after my first TCH.  I had already picked out a wig and she had it ready for me. I hadn't had my hair cut or colored since before my diagnosis so it was pretty ratty and it had begun to fall out by the handful.  I decided that the hair would be gone on my terms when the fall out began.  My husband went with me to the wig stylist's home (where she does business for medical patients only) and to be honest by that time I was resigned to losing the hair, but definitely not happy about it.  My DH had a much harder time then I did.  I didn't watch as she buzzed my hair, but he did and was so emotional.  I really do think the anticipation of going bald was actually worse than having it happen.  Now that's not to say I have been happy about it, but I somehow came to terms with looking like Shrek!  I do have some hair now but it's fuzzy and very gray.  I tried to dye it last night...still looks gray, so I guess it's the wig for me for awhile.  Andrea, I know you will make it and will still be the same beautiful person inside.  Remember the bald look isn't permanent! Take care...Linda
Posts.Title: Hair Loss- when did you just cut it all off? alcb70 SelenaWolf

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 12:51AM linnyhopp wrote: LuvRving: You look really cute in your pic.  Love the color.  Wish I were at your point in treatment instead of just starting on Monday.  But, the sooner it starts, the sooner the hair will leave and then return, right?  Hope I don't look to Shrek-like...and hoping I look as good as you when it grows back!  Linda
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2013 03:27PM - edited Jun 18, 2013 03:29PM by linnyhopp Ablydec ~ I can certainly understand that you want your hair back for "you."  I know I would feel the same way.  I hope you see results and hope it happens really soon! My hair stylist's sister has BC and warned me that the bangs would be the slowest to actually look normal.  It's really true because as she had said, it takes a long time to grow over your forehead!  As I posted earlier, the hair on my crown and the bangs look very dried out and "fried."  Everyone keeps telling me how good it looks, but that's probably because of two things...1st - they love/like me...2nd - their hair doesn't look that way.  But, I have to say that I do feel lucky since some women never have regrowth. But, I still hope as time goes on my hair gets a better texture!  My husband told me last night that only I see it that way and told me to get over it...you can only imagine what I was thinking, but I managed to try and be humble. Lago ~ I did go to Walgreens and looked at the generic product you mentioned.  The label said it would have to be used all the time to keep regrowth happening.  Do you use it on a regular basis? I am glad so many of you are seeing progress on the regrowth.  It seems like it takes forever, but it will happen eventually...both eyebrows and hair.  The only bad part is that when it does return you will have to shave under your arms and your legs, but I can tell you it's something I am grateful for.  Take care all and happy hair!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2013 01:29PM linnyhopp wrote: Thanks, Lago.  Yes, I do take anastrozole and I did take taxotere.  Your info makes perfect sense as the crown is the main area with sparse growth and the hair is also very "fried and frizzy."  The area also is only a few inches long, it seems to be growing , but definitely not as quickly as the rest of my hair.  I am 13 months pfc, so I guess it is a wait and see situation.   I know it is crazy, but I loved my wig and the style was perfect for me.  I also LOVED how much less time it took to get ready.  That being said, I also missed my hair.  I am hoping to find out if the Nioxin would  help.  I guess I will have to do some research on that.  If anyone has any info, it would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 01:30AM - edited Apr 17, 2012 01:32AM by linnyhopp That there are many different types of breast cancer and one treatment plan does not fit all.  Many people think that BC is BC.  As we all know that isn't so...each person's journey is different and the family, friends, etc. should not try to convince the BC patient that their choices are what their loved one must do to treat their illness.  It is a personal choice for the patient to do what their gut and heart feel is right for them.  This is definitely not a one treatment fits all situation.
